title: Top fashion designer leads a double life saving tigers
text:
Marion Hume International Fashion Editor Oct 31, 2019 — 12.00am Share

Anyone who follows Kim Jones on Instagram (@mrkimjones) will know that the creative director of Dior Homme, who is widely considered the leading menswear designer on earth, basically posts on two subjects: Dior – designing collections, collaborating with artists, winning multiple awards while his best mates David Beckham, Kate Moss and Naomi Campbell wear the clothes; and obscure animals – be these humpback whales (he recently swam with them in Tahiti) or pangolin (spotted on a trip to Namibia).

Jones grew up in the Amazon, Ecuador and Botswana with his father, who was a hydrogeologist. While entirely comfortable in the fashionable world of Paris, he is equally adept at being off-grid.

Don’t even think about trying to track him down off-season. He’ll be in a desert with his phone switched off, hanging out with some creature you probably never knew existed.

I know this. I used to consult for the United Nations’ ITC Ethical Fashion Initiative and, while he was still in his old job as menswear designer at Louis Vuitton, I called on Jones in order to persuade him to use cloth woven by marginalised artisans in Burkina Faso.

“Do they work anywhere near the habitat of the hamadryas baboon?” he asked. Which remains the least expected question I have ever received on planet fashion.

Of course, all of us know we only have one planet. What keeps Jones awake at night is animals becoming extinct, specifically tigers, which he adores. This is why I am phoning him when he is somewhere north of Bangkok on a moving train.

Jones is aboard the Tiger Express, aka the glamorous Eastern & Oriental Express, which has been renamed, for one journey only in aid of Save Wild Tigers, to raise awareness that, unless we wise up, the days of wild tigers are numbered.
description: When Dior Homme creative director Kim Jones isn't designing luxury menswear and dressing celebrities, he's trying to stop the extinction of animals.
